Description: Nearly 200,000 Americans have gastroenteropancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (NETs), more than esophageal, gastric, and pancreatic cancers combined, and second only to colon cancer among gastrointestinal cancers.  Moreover, the incidence of these tumors has increased >6-fold in the last four decades.  Clinical outcomes of NET patients are variable due to heterogeneous tumor biology, ranging from indolent to highly aggressive.  Although tumor stage and grade are used to predict outcomes in NET patients, patients with similar stage and grade may still have variability in clinical course.  For this reason, there is great need for additional prognostic markers to guide treatment decisions. .Systems pathology approaches, developed for other cancers, may further aid in predicting NET outcomes. We hypothesize that novel object-oriented image analyses using features such as tissue architecture, tumor cell distribution, and composition can provide information beyond the usual pathologic staging system.
SearchResultBody: ME12. Predicting Outcomes in Neuroendocrine Tumors
Title: Predicting Outcomes in Neuroendocrine Tumors
